useStmt.citReq:
Publications and research reports based on the ATUS database must cite it appropriately. The citation should include the following:
Sandra L. Hofferth, Sarah M. Flood, Matthew Sobek and Daniel Backman. American Time Use Survey Data Extract Builder: Version 2.8 [dataset]. College Park, MD: University of Maryland and Minneapolis, MN: IPUMS, 2020. https://doi.org/10.18128/D060.V2.8
The licensing agreement for use of ATUS data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography: http://bibliography.ipums.org/
useStmt.conditions:
Users of ATUS data must agree to abide by the conditions of use. A user's license is valid for one year and may be renewed. Users must agree to the following conditions:
(1) No fees may be charged for use or distribution of the data. All persons are granted a limited license to use these data, but you may not charge a fee for the data if you distribute it to others.
(2) Cite IPUMS appropriately. For information on proper citation, refer to the citation requirement section of this DDI document.
(3) Tell us about any work you do using the IPUMS. Publications, research reports, or presentations making use of ATUS should be added to our Bibliography. Continued funding for the IPUMS depends on our ability to show our sponsor agencies that researchers are using the data for productive purposes.
(4) Use it for GOOD -- never for EVIL.
useStmt.disclaimer: The user of the data acknowledges that the original collector of the data, the authorized distributor of the data, and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences based upon such uses.

fileTxt.filePlac: Minnesota Population Center, 50 Willey Hall, 225 - 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55455

var.name: RECTYPE
var.txt: RECTYPE assigns all household records the value "1"; person records are assigned "2"; activity records are assigned "3"; who records are assigned "4"; and eldercare records are assigned "5". This allows users to discriminate between different types of records in the data. Each household record is followed by one or more person records. ATUS respondents (LINENO=1) are followed by many activity records, which comprise the main time diary component of the data. Respondents may report many people with whom the activity was done; accordingly these records follow the activities to which they correspond. Finally, in 2011 forward, eldercare records include information about the individuals to whom the ATUS respondent has provided care.

var.name: YEAR
var.txt:
YEAR reports the survey year.
There are several other variables that report date information on the diary day. See DATE for the date of the diary day, DAY for the day of the diary day, and MONTH for the month of the diary day.
The ATUS interview took place 2-5 months after the final CPS interview. Date information is also available for the final CPS interview. See MONTH_CPS8 for the month of the final CPS interview and YEAR_CPS8 for the year of the final CPS interview.
var.codInstr: YEAR is a four-digit numeric variable reporting the survey year.

var.name: CASEID
var.txt:
CASEID is an identifying number unique to each household.
CASEID is the same as TUCASEID which is on the public use ATUS files. For user convenience CASEID has been converted to a numeric variable. Users who are trying to match ATUS-X files with public use ATUS files must be sure that CASEID and TUCASEID are of the same type.
var.codInstr: CASEID is a 14-digit numeric variable uniquely identifying each household.

var.name: FAMINCOME
var.txt:
FAMINCOME reports the family's total annual income.
This measure includes the income of all members of the household who are 15 years of age or older. Income includes money from jobs; net income from business, farm or rent; pensions; dividends; interest; Social Security payments; and any other monetary income received by family members.
FAMINCOME was drawn from the final CPS interview, conducted 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Family income was not updated at the time of the ATUS interview. However, individual earnings data for ATUS respondents was collected during the ATUS interview. See EARNWEEK and HOURWAGE.

var.name: PERNUM
var.txt:
PERNUM is constructed to uniquely identify each person within a given household. It is available for all household members whether they were present in the household at the time of the ATUS, CPS, or both. This is the only line number variable available for each person in every household.
LINENO was assigned to all household members present at the time of the ATUS interview. LINENO_CPS8 was assigned to all household members present at the time of the final CPS interview, 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Because household composition could change, PERNUM, LINENO, and LINENO_CPS8 may not match.

var.name: LINENO
var.txt:
LINENO identifies each person within a given ATUS respondent household. It is only available for individuals who were in an ATUS respondent household at the time of the ATUS interview. ATUS respondents always have a LINENO value of 1.
LINENO_CPS8 is a person identifier that was assigned at the time of the final CPS interview, 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Because household composition may have changed between the dates of the CPS and ATUS interviews, LINENO and LINENO_CPS8 may not match.
PERNUM is an additional person identifier that is available for all person records in the dataset.

var.name: WT06
var.txt:
WT06 provides ATUS respondent weights based on the weighting methodology introduced in 2006. WT06 is available for all years and is the preferred weighting variable to use for most analyses. It is the only weighting variable that is suitable for use in analyses that combine time use data from 2006 and later with data for earlier years. The methodology used to construct WT06 ensures that the sums of the respondent weights add up to the appropriate number of weekday person-days and weekend person-days over the quarter, both for the population as a whole and for selected subpopulations.
All ATUS weights are probability weights. Users should take care to specify them properly in their statistical packages.
Because the ATUS sample is not a simple random sample, standard errors calculated using the default options in most statistical packages will not be correct. Calculation of correct standard errors requires the use of replicate weights. RWT06 may be used in conjunction with WT06 for this purpose; for further details, see the description of RWT06.
var.codInstr: WT06 is a 16-digit numeric variable reporting the ATUS respondent probability weights. This variable can be used in all years.

var.name: SPOUSEPRES
var.labl: Spouse or unmarried partner in household
var.txt:
SPOUSEPRES reports whether the ATUS respondent has a spouse or unmarried partner living in the household.
SPOUSEPRES was collected at the time of the ATUS interview.

catgry.labl: No spouse or unmarried partner present

var.name: SPAGE
var.txt:
SPAGE reports the age in years of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner.
An individual's age is reported as of his/her last birthday.
Some ages reported are too young for marriage. Users will need to decide what to do with the illogical values.
var.codInstr:
SPAGE is a 3-digit numeric variable reporting the age in years of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner. This variable ranges between 0-85 with the exception of 81-84 (see top codes).
996 = Refused 997 = Don't know 998 = Blank 999 = NIU (Not in universe)
2003-2004: 80 years. 2005+: 85 years. Persons aged 80-84 are assigned a code of 80 and persons age 85+ are assigned a code of 85.

var.name: SPSEX
var.labl: Sex of respondent's spouse or unmarried partner
var.txt: SPSEX reports whether the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner is male or female.

var.name: SPRACE
var.txt:
SPRACE reports the racial category of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner. More than one race may be reported.
RACE was drawn from the final CPS interview, conducted 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Spouse or unmarried partner race was not updated at the time of the ATUS interview. Therefore, respondents whose spouse or unmarried partner was not in the household at the time of the CPS interview have a value of 9998 for SPRACE because information on race is not available.
In addition, SPRACE is missing for spouses of ATUS respondents whose last CPS interview occurred in 2002. RACE values for these ATUS respondents were hand-imputed using information collected using the pre-2003 CPS race categories, which did not allow for more than one race to be reported. No imputation was done for ATUS non-respondents or for other members of respondents' households. Only ATUS interviews conducted between January 2003 and May 2003 are affected by this problem.

var.name: SPHISPAN
var.txt:
SPHISPAN identifies and classifies respondent's spouse or unmarried partner as a person of Hispanic/Spanish/Latino origin. SPHISPAN data come from two questions: one which ascertains whether the person is Spanish, Hispanic, or Latino, and a second which reports country of origin information for individuals who are Spanish, Hispanic, or Latino.
SPHISPAN was drawn from the final CPS interview, conducted 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Spouse or unmarried partner ethnicity was not updated at the time of the ATUS interview. Therefore, respondents whose spouse or unmarried partner was not in the household at the time of the CPS interview have a value of 9998 for SPHISPAN because information on Hispanic origin is not available.

var.name: SPEDUC
var.labl: Highest level of school completed (spouse or partner)
var.txt:
SPEDUC reports the highest completed level of education of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner.
SPEDUC was drawn from the final CPS interview, conducted 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Spouse or unmarried partner's education was not updated at the time of the ATUS interview. Therefore, respondents whose spouse or unmarried partner was not in the household at the time of the CPS interview have a value of 998 for SPEDUC because information on education is not available.

catgry.labl: Master's degree (MA, MS, MEng, MEd, MSW, etc.)
Professional school degree (MD, DDS, DVM, etc.)

var.name: SPEMPNOT
var.txt:
SPEMPNOT reports whether the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner is employed.
For more detailed information on the employment status of the respondent's spouse, see SPEMPSTAT.
SPEMPNOT was collected at the time of the ATUS interview.

var.name: SPEMPSTAT
var.txt:
SPEMPSTAT reports the employment status of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner.
For a dichotomous variable on spouse's employment, see SPEMPNOT.
SPEMPSTAT was collected at the time of the ATUS interview.

var.name: SPUSUALHRS
var.txt:
SPUSUALHRS reports the number of hours the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner usually works per week.
SPUSUALHRS was collected at the time of the ATUS interview.

var.name: SPEARNWEEK
var.txt:
SPEARNWEEK reports the usual weekly earnings of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner in dollars.
Weekly earnings (EARNWEEK) are reported at the time of the final CPS interview, 2-5 months before the ATUS interview. Spouse's earnings are not updated at the time of the ATUS interview, though spouse's employment status (SPEMPNOT) is. Therefore, respondents whose spouse or unmarried partner was not in the household at the time of the CPS interview have a value of 99999.98 for SPEARNWEEK because information on spouse's earnings is not available.
var.codInstr:
SPEARNWEEK is a 7-digit numeric variable reported in dollars at 2 decimal places. 99999.98 = Blank 99999.99 = NIU (Not in Universe)
2003+: Usual weekly earnings of the respondent's spouse or unmarried partner greater than or equal to $2884.61 are assigned a value of $2884.61.

var.name: WB_RESP
var.txt: WB_RESP is an indicator of response to the Well-being Module [URL omitted from DDI.] of the ATUS.

var.name: RESTED
var.txt:
RESTED indicates how well-rested respondents felt yesterday when they woke up.
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.

var.name: HIGHBP
var.labl: High blood pressure in last five years
var.txt:
HIGHBP is a binary indicator of whether in the last five years the respondent was told by a doctor or other health professional that he or she had hypertension, also called high blood pressure or borderline hypertension.
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.

var.name: PAINMED
var.txt:
PAINMED is a binary indicator of whether the respondent took pain medication, such as Asprin, Ibuprofen, or prescription pain medication, yesterday.
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.

var.name: WBELIGTIME
var.labl: Minutes spent in well-being module eligible activities
var.txt:
WBELIGTIME indicates the number of minutes that Well-being Module respondents spent in activities that were eligible (see WBELIG) to be one of the three randomly selected activities about which respondents reported momentary well-being.
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.
var.codInstr: WBELIGTIME is a four-digit numeric variable.

var.name: WBTYPICAL
var.txt:
WBTYPICAL indicates what respondents thought about yesterday as a whole compared to a typical day. Respondents rate their feelings, both good and bad, compared to a typical day. They can indicate if they were better than a typical day of the week, the same as a typical day of the week, or worse than a typical of the week.
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.

var.name: WBLADDER
var.txt:
WBLADDER indicates how respondents personally feel about where they stand at present in regards to the best/worst possible life for them. On a 10-point scale, respondents are asked to imagine a ladder with steps numbered from zero at the bottom to ten at the top. The top of the ladder (step 10) represents the best possible life for them and the bottom of the ladder represents the worst possible life (step 0).
These data were collected as part of the Well-being Module of the ATUS interview. Research using this variable without activity-level quality of life data should apply WBWT as the weight in analyses; research using this variable in conjunction with activity-level quality of life data should use AWBWT for analyses.

var.name: ACTLINE
var.txt:
ACTLINE is an identifying number for each activity record. Activity records can be uniquely identified using CASEID and ACTLINE.
ACTLINE is also used with ACTLINEW to link who records to activity records.
This variable is available via extracts that are hierarchical or rectangular (activity) (more info on extract formats [URL omitted from DDI.]). If you request a hierarchical extract and plan to construct time use variables in your statistics package, this variable may be useful to you. If you request a rectangular extract and plan to construct time use variables through the extract system, ACTLINE will not be included in your extract, as persons are the unit of observation for rectangular extracts rather than activity or who records.
var.codInstr: ACTLINE is a 2-digit numeric variable identifying each activity record.

var.name: ACTIVITY
var.txt:
ACTIVITY reports the respondent's activity.
The activity is recorded as a six digit number. The first two digits correspond to a broad category, the middle two to a more detailed subcategory, and the final two to a specific activity within those categories. For example, broad category 02 refers to "Household Activities." Within "Household Activities," subcategory 01 refers to "Housework." Within that subcategory, 02 refers to "Doing laundry." The full six digit code for "Doing laundry" is therefore 020102. Analyses can be done using the first two, the first four, or all six digits of ACTIVITY.
There are a number of variables that may be used in conjunction with ACTIVITY. START and STOP record the start and stop times of the activity, respectively. DURATION records the number of minutes the activity lasted. DURATION_EXT also records the number of minutes the activity lasted, but does not truncate the last activity at 4:00 a.m. when the diary day ends. WHERE records the location of activities. Finally, the variable RELATEW records who was with the respondent during the activity. Users should note that "who" information is not collected for all activities (see WHO_ASK).
There are a number of secondary activity variables [URL omitted from DDI.] that may be used in conjunction with activity. See more information on secondary childcare [URL omitted from DDI.] and secondary eating and drinking [URL omitted from DDI.].
Users analyzing travel should be aware of how travel activities are coded in the ATUS. More information is available elsewhere [URL omitted from DDI.].
ACTIVITY is available via extracts that are hierarchical or rectangular (activity) (more info on extract formats [URL omitted from DDI.]). If you request a hierarchical extract and plan to construct time use variables in your statistics package, this variable may be useful to you. If you request a rectangular extract and plan to construct time use variables through the extract system, ACTIVITY will not be included in your extract, as persons are the unit of observation for rectangular extracts rather than activity or who records.

var.name: LINENOR
var.txt:
LINENOR reports the person line number of the eldercare recipient.
If the recipient is a household member, the recipient's line number is the same as ATUS person number (LINENO); if the recipient is not a household member, the recipient's line number takes on the value of the next available person line number in the household (last household person number+1). Users may refer to HH_EC to see whether an eldercare recipient lives in household.
var.codInstr: This is a 2-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: HH_EC
var.labl: Eldercare recipient is a household member
var.txt:
HH_EC reports whether or not the eldercare recipient is a household member.
Eldercare can be provided in either a care facility, such as a nursing home, or in a residential home setting for a household or non-household member.
Users may refer to LINENOR for more information about line number of eldercare recipient. If the recipient is a household member, recipient's line number is the same as ATUS person number (LINENO); if the recipient is not a household member, the recipient's line number takes on the value of the next available person line number in the household (last household person number+1).

catgry.labl: Recipient is not a household member

var.name: RELATER
var.labl: Relationship to respodent of person who received care
var.txt: RELATER reports the relationship of eldercare recipients to the ATUS respondent.

var.name: ECAGE
var.txt:
ECAGE reports the age of the eldercare recipient.
For household members, this is the age on the diary day; for non-household members it is the person's age on the first of the month for the month corresponding to 3 months before the interview.
To see more detailed information about the age definition, users may refer to Adding Eldercare Questions to the American Time Use Survey [URL omitted from DDI.].

var.name: ECYEAR
var.txt:
ECYEAR reports how many years the eldercare recipient has received care from the ATUS respondent.
This variable only includes recipients who received more than 1 year of eldercare from the respondent. Information about how long the recipient has received care if the care has been less than one year is available in ECMONTH. Temporary conditions that do not require ongoing care, such as a broken leg, are excluded from the definition of eldercare.
var.codInstr:
ECYEAR is a 3-digit numeric variable reporting the number of years the respondent provided care to the eldercare recipient.
NIU = 999

var.name: ECMONTH
var.txt:
ECMONTH reports how long (in months) the eldercare recipient has received care from the ATUS respondent.
Information about the number of years the recipient has received care from the respondent is available in available in ECYEAR.

var.name: Sleeping_time
var.txt: BLS: Personal care: Sleeping modification of BLS_PCARE_SLEEP from group "BLS published tables"
var.codInstr: DURATION is a 4-digit numeric variable reporting the length of the activity in minutes in one 24-hour period.

var.name: Traveling
var.txt: ACT: Traveling modification of ACT_TRAVEL from group "Activity coding structure"
var.codInstr: DURATION is a 4-digit numeric variable reporting the length of the activity in minutes in one 24-hour period.

var.name: caring_HH_adults
var.labl: BLS: Caring for and helping household members: Caring for and helping household adults
var.txt: BLS: Caring for and helping household members: Caring for and helping household adults modification of BLS_CAREHH_ADULT from group "BLS published tables"
var.codInstr: DURATION is a 4-digit numeric variable reporting the length of the activity in minutes in one 24-hour period.
